messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] Alan Rickman...again
messages.msgSnippet: as the villian in ... Yes,   I think its funny because he s still kind-of scrawny looking but its something about his voice and the way he delivers his
messages.messageBody:
as the villian in
> Robin Hood he oozed charm and sexiness



Yes, I think its funny because he's still kind-of scrawny looking but its something about his voice and the way he delivers his lines,,,hmmmmmmmm.



The outtakes from the first Harry Potter were great with him, I think Shyrley already commented on these tho'. Of course, <g>



I havn't seen Truely, Madly, Deeply yet, is he a good guy or bad guy, I'm thinking I like him best when he's bad!



Kelli





Earthmomma67@... wrote:

starsuncloud@... writes:

> Oh, but before you do that, you MUST see him in "Sense and
> Sensiblities"....only then can you declare yourself unaffected by his
> charms.
> :)
> As Snape he is not wildly attractive of course, but even as the villian in
> Robin Hood he oozed charm and sexiness.
>
>
I will do so.
Elissa

messages.subject: Alan Rickman...again
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 12/17/02 7:09:38 PM Central Standard Time, Unschooling-dotcom@yahoogroups.com writes:
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 12/17/02 7:09:38 PM Central Standard Time,
Unschooling-dotcom@yahoogroups.com writes:

<< Oh I'm so glad I'm not the only one who doesn't see it. Maybe we can start
out own little not a fan club!! >>

Oh, but before you do that, you MUST see him in "Sense and
Sensiblities"....only then can you declare yourself unaffected by his charms.
:)
As Snape he is not wildly attractive of course, but even as the villian in
Robin Hood he oozed charm and sexiness.

Ren
"Knowledge will not always take the place of simple observation."
~Arnold Lobel
